review_title: Well...  It's a Consulting Agency.  My Experience as a Remote Worker.
job_title: Application Development Analyst in Nashville, TN
pros:
- The culture has been great for the most part. People are friendly and leadership is about 90% non-toxic.

- The benefits aren't bad. Aside from health insurance, 401K, etc... you get access to the Benefits Hub which has some great deals.

- The work is usually stress-free
cons:
TL;DR: The role-finding system is - for lack of a better term: a waste of time
---
I'm a Software Engineer. 

In the nearly two years I've worked for Accenture, I've only gotten to work on a relevant role for 1 month. 

The remaining time was spent working on irrelevant, extremely boring projects, performing tasks far below my skill level - which did not enable me to improve the skills I am passionate about.

Between projects, we are expected to find roles on our own. If we don't find a role quickly enough, we're shoehorned into another irrelevant, boring project.

Finding roles to fill is not the hard part, there are tons of them available. The hard part is getting the POCs for those roles to even bother responding to you. One person 'liked' my message on MS Teams and I never heard from them again.

review_title: The Best Position to Apply For! But...
job_title: Application Developer Associate in Austin, TX
pros:
When I joined Accenture, I did through the Apprentice Program. This is a year-long "job interview", putting you into a usual position at Accenture for an Associate level, and if you meet the business criteria, you join! If not, you don't, but you have a whole year of experience at a company like this.

The benefits are affordable, the PTO allowances are huge, most projects are work from home. and it's overall a great jumpstart to a career in tech.
cons: While my cons are few, it's important for anyone joining this program. You are not gonna have your hand held. You will be expected to login at your usual times, you have to do the work with efficiency, you'll be expected to be available throughout the work day; this may all seem obvious. But for people, like me, that are new to an environment like this, do not get comfortable. Time will catch up to you, and while people will help you succeed, you have to take that initative.

pros: A lot of departments, yearly bonus and top private healthcare insurance.
cons: Salary differs significantly from town to town (Cluj - Targu Mures), though you do the same thing. I received less than I asked initially, and the explanation was that I might have received that amount if I was at Cluj. You don't get a raise after the first year, only in the second, and that rarely covers the inflation.

review_title: Accenture was great, Boomerang was not
pros: I worked at Boomerang when it was under Accenture, but before it was fully absorbed (from 2018-2020). The positives were that the company was under Accenture and the benefits were incredible. Accenture is a pro employee company with some great projects and expectations were high, which I did not mind.
cons:
Some of the people who worked in Boomerang were reprehensible. Upper management encouraged backstabbing and throwing people under the bus was a weekly occurrence as people were constantly in self preservation mode. I came into this company with 10 years of experience in the digital and search field and had started a successful company from scratch AND sold it, yet I had never been so disrespected in my entire life. By people who had less experience than me, go figure that one.

Every day was a disaster because this company was still in a startup feel, yet it had the backing of a gigantic company such as Accenture. Everyone would be running around like chickens with their heads cut off and the same recurring problems would pop up over and over again.
